Claude.passage: Claude is a given name. It is a French form of the English name "Claudius", which is derived from the Roman gens Claudia. The name was introduced into France by the Normans.

qae_pairs.question: In what country is the name Claude derived from?
qae_pairs.explanation: Claude is a French form of the English name Claudius, which is derived from the Roman gens Claudia. The name was introduced into France by the Normans.

Monet.passage: Monet Claude-Camille (French pronunciation: ​[monɑ̃ ˈkloʁe ʔkamjʁi]; French: [moɲɑ̃ klouʀ ɡamʁi]; English: [mohˈnɛ]; 7 December 1840 – 29 December 1926) was a French Impressionist painter and a pivotal figure in the development of 20th-century art. He is considered by some to be the father of modern art. His best-known series of work, the Water Lilies, are some of the most reproduced images in art history. He is often referred to as the \"father of impressionism\" or the \"father of post-impressionism\", although he himself rejected these labels. He was one of the first artists to abandon the detailed, carefully composed studio painting in favor of painting en plein air, or in the open air, and his later works are noted for their broken color and light effects. Monet is considered one of the most important and influential artists of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. He is often ranked among the most important artists of the 19th century and one of the most influential artists of all time, and he is sometimes called the "Leonardo of the 20th century".

qae_pairs.question: What is the date of birth of the person who is considered by some to be the father of modern art?
qae_pairs.explanation: Claude Monet was born on 7 December 1840.

qae_pairs.question: What was the date of death of the artist who was born on 7 December 1840?
qae_pairs.explanation: Claude Monet was born on 7 December 1840 and died on 29 December 1926.

Vincent.passage: Vincent van Gogh, also spelled van Goch, (30 March 1853 – 29 March 1890) was a Dutch post-Impressionist painter. He is considered one of the most influential figures in the development of 20th-century art. He was born in Zundert, in the southern province of North Brabant, as the son of a Protestant minister. Van Gogh moved to Amsterdam to study theology but was unable to accept a life of duty and discipline and was baptized a Roman Catholic in 1875. He worked as an art dealer and submitted paintings to art salons, but struggled to make a living. In 1886, he moved to the village of Nuenen, where he was inspired by the surrounding countryside to produce some of his most memorable works. He suffered from mental illness throughout his life, and died in 1890, aged 37, following a gunshot wound inflicted by his friend and fellow artist, painter Paul Gauguin. Van Gogh's work had little impact during his lifetime, but in the years following his death, he became widely admired. His reputation has grown steadily since the late 20th century and he is now widely regarded as one of the most significant figures in the history of art, and one of the most popular and influential painters of all time. He was an extremely prolific artist, completing about 2,200 paintings in his lifetime. He left behind about 1,800 paintings and 800 drawings.

qae_pairs.question: Where was Vincent van Gogh born?
qae_pairs.explanation: Vincent van Gogh was born in Zundert, in the southern province of North Brabant.

qae_pairs.question: Question: What was the name of the person who shot Vincent van Gogh?
qae_pairs.explanation: In 1890, Vincent van Gogh was shot by his friend and fellow artist, Paul Gauguin.

qae_pairs.question: What is the date of birth of the person who was born in Zundert, in the southern province of North Brabant?
qae_pairs.explanation: Vincent van Gogh was born on 30 March 1853 in Zundert, in the southern province of North Brabant.

Cézanne.passage:
Jean-Paul Cézanne (/ˈtʃɑːnə/; French: [ʒɑ̃ paʁ ʃɛzɑ̃]; 22 October 1839 – 22 January 1906) was a French artist who is considered one of the key figures in the development of modern art. [1] He is particularly noted for developing the concept of painting "nature itself" (l'essence de la réalité), which was a major influence on the development of cubism and post-impressionism. [2] He worked in a variety of media including oil painting, watercolor, drawing, and printmaking. Cézanne was a prolific artist and his oeuvre includes over 2,000 works, many of which have been lost. [3] He is also known for being a perfectionist and often working on the same painting for years. [4]
Cézanne's early life was shaped by his family's financial difficulties, and by his father's death when he was eleven. He began his art studies in Aix-en-Provence and later attended the École des Beaux-Arts in Paris. [5] He became a professor of drawing there from 1879 to his death in 1906.

qae_pairs.question: What year did Cézanne become a professor of drawing?
qae_pairs.explanation: Cézanne became a professor of drawing in 1879.

qae_pairs.question: When was Cézanne born?
qae_pairs.explanation: Jean-Paul Cézanne was born on 22 October 1839.

Picasso.passage: Pablo Picasso (Spanish: [ˈpakso]; 25 October 1881 – 8 April 1973) was a Spanish painter, sculptor, printmaker, ceramicist, and poet. He was a pivotal figure in the Modern art movement. Picasso's varied artistic output encompassed painting, sculpture, printmaking, ceramics, and drawing, and his work has been widely influential in the visual arts. He was a master of many techniques of the visual arts, including the collage of Picabia, the realism of Renoir, the naturalism of Cézanne, the still life of Matisse, and the abstraction of Braque and Gris. Picasso is regarded as one of the most important and influential artists of the 20th century. His wide-ranging work had a significant impact on the development of 20th-century art, and he is among the most celebrated painters of all time. He was a key figure in the avant-garde movements of cubism and surrealism, and his works are widely collected and exhibited. Picasso was born in Malaga, Spain, to an upper middle-class family of Italian descent. He left home at 17 and moved to Barcelona, where he was trained as a painter in a traditional academic style. He soon became a key member of the avant-garde group Les Vauvilliers. In 1901, he moved to Paris, the center of the art world.

qae_pairs.explanation: Picasso was born in Malaga, Spain, to an upper middle-class family of Italian descent.

qae_pairs.explanation: Picasso was a member of the avant-garde group Les Vauvilliers.

Works, Transport and Communication.passage: The Works, Transport and Communication Union (German: Gewerkschaft Erde-Transport- und Verkehr) was a trade union in Germany, representing transport and communication workers. The union was founded in 1949, as the successor to the Railway Transport Union, and was one of two major unions for railway workers in West Germany. In 1970, the union merged with the Union of Communication and Electrical Workers to form IG BCE.

Parliament.passage: The Parliament of England was a bicameral legislature in England and Wales from the 13th century until the English Civil War. It was composed of two chambers: the House of Commons and the House of Lords. The House of Commons was elected by the lower and middle classes, and was designed to represent the interests of the people. The House of Lords was composed of members of the aristocracy, and was designed to protect the interests of the aristocracy.
